sections.Entry requirements:
To be eligible to the course, the student should have a Bachelor's degree in any subject,
or have successfully completed 90 credits of studies in computer science, software
engineering, or equivalent.
Specifically, at least 15 credits of successfully completed courses in programming, of
which at least 7.5 credits in Python programming, or equivalent are required. The
student needs to have successfully completed a course in probability theory or statistics,
for example DIT862 or MSG810 or similar, and a course on algorithms and data
structures, or equivalent. DIT375 fulfills both Python and algorithm and data structures
requirements.
Applicants must prove knowledge of English: English 6/English B or the equivalent level
of an internationally recognized test, for example TOEFL, IELTS.
sections.Learning outcomes:
On successful completion of the course the student will be able to:
Knowledge and understanding
• explain computational problems arising from questions of biological importance in
the analysis of omics data
• discuss important algorithmic aspects when designing and implementing
bioinformatics solutions for genome-scale data,
• describe data structures and algorithms for genome-scale data and discuss their
utility
Competence and skills
•
•
implement applications for analyzing genome-scale data with different
bioinformatics frameworks,
use algorithms and datastructures for computations with genome-scale data
Judgement and approach
•
suggest appropriate methodological approaches for analysis tasks and discuss their
advantages and drawbacks,
• discuss advantages and drawbacks of different computational models for biological
questions involving genome-scale data,
sections.Course content:
The aim of this course is to deepen the students' knowledge and skills and familiarize
them with the exciting field of bioinformatics for genome-scale data. The course will
introduce aspects of designing and implementing large-scale bioinformatics solutions for
genomes, transcriptomes and other omics data.
In particular, the course will include:
•
•
an overview of bioinformatics problems, algorithmic approaches, and high-
performance techniques to processing genome-scale data,
an introduction to data structures such as index structures including suffix trees,
suffix arrays, the Burrows-Wheeler transform and the FM-index
• an introduction to alignment-free methods including k-mer based approaches as
well as approximate computation approaches such as sketching
• implementation of bioinformatics workflows on a cluster using appropriate software
frameworks,
• Case studies applying the methods to real-world data sets.

sections.Assessment:
The course is examined by a final project, as well as mandatory written assignments,
some of which will be carried out individually and others will be carried out in groups of
normally 2-3 students. There will be non-obligatory individual assignments which grant
bonus points for the final project. These bonus points are valid for the two next
scheduled re- examinations.
A student who has taken two exams in a course or part of a course without obtaining a
pass grade is entitled to the nomination of another examiner. The student needs to
contact the department for a new examiner, preferably in writing, and this should be
approved by the department unless there are special reasons to the contrary (Chapter 6
Section 22 of the Higher Education Ordinance).
If a student has received a recommendation from the University of Gothenburg for
special educational support, where it is compatible with the learning outcomes of the
course and provided that no unreasonable resources are required, the examiner may
decide to allow the student to sit an adjusted exam or alternative form of assessment.
In the event that a course has ceased or undergone major changes, students are to be
guaranteed at least three examination sessions (including the ordinary examination
session) over a period of at least one year, but no more than two years, after the course
has ceased/been changed. The same applies to placements and professional placements
(VFU), although this is restricted to just one additional examination session.
sections.Grades:
The grading scale comprises: Pass with distinction (5), Pass with credit (4), Pass (3) and
Fail (U).
To pass the course, students must receive a passing grade in both modules. The grade
for the entire course will be determined by the final project.
sections.Course evaluation:
The course is evaluated through meetings both during and after the course between
teachers and student representatives. Further, an anonymous questionnaire is used to
ensure written information. The outcome of the evaluations serves to improve the
course by indication which parts could be added, improved, changed or removed.
